These plugin specific subroutines of this shader are only used in this shader:
-   addInit() //initial state == onInit() dot[x] positions

-   branchi()
Shared Common Subroutines
- see CommonTab: modifiables for diecetic_UI_2
- const v3 deleteRect  AxisAlignedBound (red deletion rectangle)
- inRect(uv,deleteRect) //contextBoundFilter
iDiegeticUI has lots of visualization code, likely only needed in ImageTab
- drawDragDots()

--- pseudocode structure:

iDiegeticUI buffers a list of dot[x]
, for a dragAndDrop UI (in screenspace)
, and one fragment buffers [number of dots]

Any other shader can read these dot-coordinates
, commonly used to modify parameters of parametricFunctions:
- parametric CSG (debug/demo frustrumCulling or AutomaticDifferentiation)
- - [megaprm]
- - "implicit" splines/isosurfaces

this buffer stors states that set:
- number of stored states
-.xy coordinate of points for [diecetic UI]

/**/ //end__ plugin notes:


/*
diecetic /screenspace UI = reusable drag&drop

parent     : https://www.shadertoy.com/view/Xt3BzX
parent     : https://www.shadertoy.com/view/4dtSRn
Inspired by: https://www.shadertoy.com/view/MdKGRw
reusable drag and drop framework; by mhnewman
- Drag objects around by clicking on them.
- Add new objects by clicking in space.
- Delete objects by dragging them to the red square.

buffOfDot(v0(floor(x))) function returns parameters of dot[x]
- THIS shader should not contain buffOfDot()
- , but instead most likely just the [ImageTab] for a screenspace UI

maxCount := the maximum number of objects that can be represented.
Buffer pixels (0, 0) to (maxCount - 1, 0) := the coordinates of each object.
  * .x := the object's x coordinate.
  * .y := the object's y coordinate.

 Buffer pixel (maxCount, 0) := the current state.
  * .x := the index of the currently selected object.
  * .y := the number of active objects.
  * .z := the mouse state.

 Buffer pixel (maxCount + 1, 0) := the mouse offset from the center of the current object.

/**/

//pluginName= iAD
/*
iChannel0=BuffA,iChannel1=BuffB,iChannel2=BuffC,iChannel3=BuffD

/**/ //--- srart AD-Modifiers 
//these can be twiddled with, without breaking much

#define SuperPrim

#define thick .1
//line thickness

#define scene 2
//scene: theres 2 scene-layers, a 2d scene and a 3d scene:
//domains 1 <-> 2d
//domains 2 <-> 3d
//domains 3 <-> mix(3d,2d)

#define IterRm 64.
//max raymarch iterations|steps

#define IterSh 16.
//softshadow iterations
 
#define ReciprocalAbsLipschitz 1.
//if(lipschitzConstant>1., distance is overestimated.
//multiplying by ReciprocalAbsLipschitz is a 
//... lazy fix for that is scaling stepDistance*=ReciprocalAbsLipschitz
//higher precision with a smaller ReciprocalAbsLipschitz AND epsilon=0.
//meaning, a surface will NEVER really be reached.
//maybe todo: eps=log(eps*b)*a

#define camLens 2.
//fieldOfView

#define camRoll 0.
//camera lens and roll for camera projection matrix (is not a quaternion camera)


//below code can be twiddled, easily breaking more things

v0 viewZoom(v0 t,v1 u,v2 r,v3 m){return 1.;}
#define viewzoom 1.

/**/ //--- end__ AD-Modifiers
     //
/**/ //--- start AD-calculus-Intro
/*

This demoes [AutomaticDifferentiation]==[AD]
-,that automatically calculates the NthDerivative of (m)any function(s)
- , by implementing:
- -    chainRule (top level function)
- -  productRule (arises out of chainRule 2nd derivative)
- - quotientRule (reciprocal productRule)
- -    powerRule:

self   AD35 : https://www.shadertoy.com/view/WtfGRS
parent AD26c: https://www.shadertoy.com/view/WtXGW4
parent AD34 : https://www.shadertoy.com/view/Wlf3WN
parent AD26 : https://www.shadertoy.com/view/MsffRs
granny AD24 : https://www.shadertoy.com/view/XdXfRl
uncle       : https://www.shadertoy.com/view/XlV3Dy (goursat)
aunt        : https://www.shadertoy.com/view/MsXBRB (simpler shapes)
granddad    : https://www.shadertoy.com/view/4dVGzw (swiveled)

general automatic differentiation is:
- based on    : https://www.shadertoy.com/view/4dVGzw
- inspired by : https://www.shadertoy.com/view/Mdl3Ws 
- explained at: http://blog.demofox.org/2014/12/30/dual-numbers-automatic-differentiation/
- wiki        : https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automatic_differentiation
- summary:    : https://www.reddit.com/r/math/comments/68st6p/the_wikipedia_article_on_automatic/

The details/axiomes/rules of this are explained in the CommonTab implementation
You do not need to know ALL its rules to know how to use it
But it helps oif you are good in physics, and know what [Inertia] means/models.

This likely makes much more sense
, if you first calculate the (double) integral of your function
, with something like:    https://www.integral-calculator.com/
, And then use AD to derive that precalculated integral back to its original, for:
- precise/analytic [filter] [anti-alasing] (by starting from a DoubleIntegral)
- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Contour_integration
-Fluid dynamics, pressure waves (With a buffer over time)
-EM-fields: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Surface_integral
Specific analytic filters are done regularily by InigoQuilez
, mostly noise with analytic first derivatives:
-  iquilezles.org/articles/morecheckerfiltering
-  https://iquilezles.org/articles/filtering
-  https://iquilezles.org/articles/filterableprocedurals
-  https://iquilezles.org/articles/gradientnoise
-  https://iquilezles.org/articles/morenoise
- - IQ stateless (no LookUpTable/texture/VBO) 2d and 3d noise (with analytic derivatives) 
  - - Value    Noise 2d 1st Derivative:  https://www.shadertoy.com/view/4dXBRH
  - - Gradient Noise 2d 1st Derivative:  https://www.shadertoy.com/view/XdXBRH
  - - Value    Noise 3d 1st Derivative:  https://www.shadertoy.com/view/XsXfRH
  - - Gradient Noise 3d 1st Derivative:  https://www.shadertoy.com/view/4dffRH
  - - Value    Noise 2d 0th Derivative:  https://www.shadertoy.com/view/lsf3WH
  - - Value    Noise 3d 0th Derivative:  https://www.shadertoy.com/view/4sfGzS
  - - Gradient Noise 2d 0th Derivative:  https://www.shadertoy.com/view/XdXGW8
  - - Gradient Noise 3d 0th Derivative:  https://www.shadertoy.com/view/Xsl3Dl
  - - Simplex  Noise 2d 0th Derivative:  https://www.shadertoy.com/view/Msf3WH
- - 
AD allows you to automate this, with up to a 3th derivative, over up to 4 domains.
You calculate thedouble Integral of any function, and AD calculates you 3 derivatves for a [filter]
This works over up to 4 domains, this is multivariate-calculis, right?

I mean, tthis can solve for optimization problems of a
  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Partial_derivative
, right?

[AD]==[Automatic Differentiation] implies the
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chain_rule
to cheaply calculate derivatives as byproduct of a set of operands
with specific data types

- - All derivatives let you smoothen line-thickness without multi-tapping.
- - All derivatives let you better esttimate AO or shadows

1st derivative is useful for
- precise surface normals
- more precise surface normals. (better normals on corners)
- some adcanced-spheretracking optimizazions
2nd derivative is useful for 
- precise surface curvature (better scatter/subsurface
- some adcanced-spheretracking optimizazions
2nd derivative is useful for 
- well its 3d equivalent [instant changeRate of curvature] lacks a name...
- and some adcanced-spheretracking optimizazions

precision or performance increases more
- near sharp corners
- with shapes|functions, that lack C0|C1-continuity but have C1|C2-continuity.
- - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smoothness

The "art" here is to define an implicit isosurface
 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Implicit_surface
 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isosurface
 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qb40J4N1fa4
That way you get all the Contour lines, gradients, normals...
 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Contour_line
 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gradient
 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Surface_normal
...along all the domains (dimensions) of a surface
 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Surface_%28topology%29
...very cheaply, because the contour is orthogonal to the gradient.

how about some fast lacplachians:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laplace_operator

2nd derivatives (of the ChainRule) have tricky property
that it likely adds a product or fraction, which implies a
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Product_rule
or
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quotient_rule
as subroutine

We commonly differentiate over [t] so any "dx" is replaced by "dt"
this evades confusion beween [t]th derivatives and [.x] as domain space
where displacement over time is most common:

todo. list [differentials of displacement over time]

eg: absement=antiderivative of position over time == distance*time == homesickness
eg: a [long shortDistance relationship] 
   == [short longDistance relationship] in terms of [abserment]
BUT t may also be a spartial domain
eg: the [antiderivative of position over space] actually makes sense


/**/ //--- end__ AD-calculus-Intro
     //
/**/ //--- start AD-calculus-Overview
/*

r=f(a); is the general form of a function f(a), something like:
v0 f(v0 a){return 3.*a*a*a+2.*a*a-a+7.;}
;
AutomaticDifferentiation calculates the derivatives of f(a):
;
A [deritative of [f(a)] over [a]]
is the INSTANTANEOUS [rate of change] of [f(a)] over [a]
The lazy approach is to measure different 2 points of f(a)
and calculate the slope between these points
- This is how most shaders on shadertoy calculate a surfaceNormal
- - They commonly measure 2x3 points, 2 points along each of the 3 orrthogonal axes in 3d
- - - That is not the INSTANTANEOUS [rate of change], but more like a lowPrecisionAverage [rate of change]
A [deritative of [f(a)] is the limit of this slope-angle when length(slope) approaches 0.
;
A [derivative of a [    derivative]] is a [2nd derivative], aka [gradient]
A [derivative of a [2nd derivative]] is a [3nd derivative]
;
exmaple speed_velocity:
A function, that returns the position of something for any time-input
, returns a [pos=position(time) over [time]]:
v0 position(v0 t){return 3.*a*a*a+2.*a*a-a+7.;}//input time returns position
;
The derivative of the position() function returns the speed(time) (or velocity in more than 1d)
v0 speed(v0 t){return  9.*a*a+4.*a-1.;}//input time returns speed
;
The derivative of the speed() function returns the Accelleration(time)
v0 speed(v0 t){return 18.*a+4;}//input time returns Accelleration
;
The derivative of the Accelleration() function returns the Jounce(time) (the rate of change of accelleration)
v0 speed(v0 t){return 18.;}//input time returns Jounce

"Jounce" is by far not the strangest derived-SI-unit's properNoun here:

/**/ //--- end__ AD-calculus-Overview
     //
/**/ //--- start AD-common-derived-[SIunit]s, sorted by derivatives.
/*

When we derive over something, we derive over (compositions of)
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_System_of_Units
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SI_derived_unit

It helps to define common properNouns
, to talk about concepts/predictions and correlations
I shortened some terms (to single-glyph-length), for better monospaced-text
Uppercase labels [T,L,M,I,K,N,J] are nameOfDomain
Lowercase labels [s,m,g,a,e,o,c] are nameOfInitial
Sorted, by how commonly we derive ofer these units:
-       time()SIunit==[T]==[s]Second
-     length()SIunit==[L]==[m]Meter
-       mass()SIunit==[M]==[g](kilo)Gramm  //aka [linear inertia]
-    current()SIunit==[I]==[a]Ampere
-temperature()SIunit==[K]==[e]kElvin       //[K] may also be [capitalized "omega"]
-     amount()SIunit==[N]==[o]mOle
-luminousity()SIunit==[J]==[c]Candela

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metrology#Legal_metrology

/**/ //--- start AD-common-derived-[SIunit]s, sorted by derivatives
     //
/**/ //--- start AD-common-derivatives over time,dT,T^(n-1)
/*
Some labels are only scalar, or only linear, or only angular
The lists below do not care much about that, for now it is a hot mess
, and it is up to you to properly calculate in carthesian or polar space.

Sometimes some notations/labels are more intuitive than others
For a simple start, we assert that 
- Time is scalar and measured in seconds=[s]
- Time has only one dimension (at least true for past experiences)
- - Otherwise causality is an [arbitiary field] and math of that gets a bit too [statistic]al
;
for simpler syntax, we first to derive over [s] and label [Nth derivatives over s] as:
[0th derivative of f(s)]= s =f(s)         =f   (s)=f0(s)=a.a=b.a=c.a
[1th derivative of f(s)]=ds =f(s)*ds      =f'  (s)=f1(s)=a.b=b.b=c.b
[2th derivative of f(s)]=ds²=f(s)*ds*ds   =f'' (s)=f2(s)=a.c=b.c=c.c
[3th derivative of f(s)]=ds³=f(s)*ds*ds*ds=f'''(s)=f3(s)=a.d=b.d=c.d
The above may seem trivial, but this gets messy VERY fast
to a point where you MUST know 
- how many derivatives a struct/function calculates
- what derivative of what else you are currently looking at
- what that value means in context to a unit of measure
- what domain you derive over

utility:
while(we only derive over time|s (or over ONE space-domain) (up to 3 times)
){//we can differentiate any TERM below (into an up to 3lines-Lower-TERM)
 ;//and then a higher-TERM can be used to [filter] a lower-TERM
 ;//  https://www.shadertoy.com/results?query=filter
 ;//this is done (without AD or calculus) in many shaders about motionBlur
 ;//  https://www.shadertoy.com/results?query=blur
;}
;
ITIT*==[double integral   over time   of[*]]
  IT*==       [integral   over time   of[*]]
  DT*==       [derivative over time   of[*]]
  DL*==       [derivative over length of[*]]
  RE*==                   [reciprocal of[*]]

--- position|displacement-integrals (over time|s) are:  

ITITtime =1.*s*s*s //[double integral over time of [time]]
  ITtime =1.*s*s   //       [integral over time of [time]]
    time =1.*s     //                              [time]
     unit=1.       //     [derivative over time of [time]]
frequency=1./s     //     [derivative over time of [unit]]            aka[becquerel] aka [[fluxion]==initially proposed term for [dt]]
    phase=1./s/s   //     [derivative over time of [frequency]] ==IADMtesla aka[frequencyDrift] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Instantaneous_phase
  DTphase=1./s/s/s //     [derivative over time of [phase]]
;
see: (Janzen et al. 2014) and:
http://www.thespectrumofriemannium.com/2012/11/10/log053-derivatives-of-position/
;
(wave)length ==1.*m      //beware: [relativistic length-contraction]
      Speed  ==1.*m/s    //beware: the [speed of information]==[speed of light]==min(AnySpeed,[speed of light]) 
;
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Velocity#Distinction_between_speed_and_velocity
;
length|speed are implicitly scalar,single-dimensional; length(a)=sqrt(dot(a,a)) projections onto a single domain.
below are implicitly defined as VECTORS, with more than 1domain (of space)
length-vector == Displacement|position
 speed-vector == Velocity
- They include a relative direction; length()*(angles|UnitQuaternion)
- They include all angular reference points
- ,as a polar transformation implies 2 dimensions.
- - linear/carthesian vectors are identified by starting with [ 1.*] or [ 1./]
- - polar /complex    vectors are identified by starting with [rad*] or [rad/]
- - - This often does NOT care wether you are in carthesian or polar coordinates (sometimes the labels are just mixed up)
- - - sorry, this first version of the list likely mixes terms that are not to be mixed into the same context/bucket.
- This is quite a messy collection of many nouns, some contexts are lost, some identities are typos.
- They include all issues of periodic/circular displacement
- ,where you can do a lot of work, and can end up exactly where you started, plus some entropy
- - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Directional_derivative#Normal_derivative
;
      “farness”=1.*m*s*s*s*s*s*s*s*s*s*s*s*s
         absput=1.*m*s*s*s*s*s*s*s*s*s*s*s

REaccelleration=1./m/s/s
